2025-12-10 18:04:30,130 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 4-year-old boy is brought to his primary care physician for a physical prior to beginning a preschool program. He is found to be delayed in reaching normal childhood cognitive and social milestones, which is consistent with observations at previous check-ups. Physically, he is also found to be significantly overweight with hypogonadism. Notably, the boy was limp when he was born and did not have a normal motor response to stimuli. Elevated levels of a gastrointestinal hormone are associated with the cause of this patient's weight gain. The hormone that is most responsible for causing the weight gain is produced in which of the following cell types?

[A] : D cells
[B] : G cells
[C] : P/D1 cells
[D] : L cells
<|end|><|assistant|> The clinical picture described for the 4-year-old boy suggests a condition known as congenital hypothyroidism, which is characterized by developmental delays, weight gain, hypogonadism, and a low motor response at birth. The elevated levels of a gastrointestinal hormone associated with the cause of this patient's weight gain are likely to be related to the thyroid hormone deficiency.

The gastrointestinal hormone that is most commonly associated with weight gain in the context of hypothyroidism is gastrin. Gastrin is a hormone that stimulates the secretion of gastric acid by the parietal cells of the stomach and aids in gastric motility. It is produced by G cells, which are located in the antrum of the stomach.

Given the options provided:

[A]. D cells - These cells produce somatostatin, which inhibits the release of many other hormones.
[B]. G cells - These cells produce gastrin, which can be associated with weight gain when thyroid hormone levels are low.
[C]. P/D1 cells - These cells are not a recognized cell type in the context of gastrointestinal hormone production.
[D]. L cells - These cells are found in the ileum and produce glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1), which is not directly related to weight gain in the context of hypothyroidism.

Therefore, the hormone that is most responsible for causing the weight gain in this patient, and is associated with the cause of the patient's condition, is produced by G cells.

So, the answer is [B]. G cells.<|end|>
2025-12-10 18:04:30,130 - INFO - question 702/1273 answer:B correct_answer:C False
2025-12-10 18:04:38,737 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> Accurate and rapid identification of individuals with tuberculosis (TB) is crucial to accomplishing the goal of the World Health Organization (WHO) to eliminate this disease. One of the key strategies for the detection of TB is the use of tuberculin skin testing as a globally pertinent screening method, due to its low cost and technical simplicity. A study from Brazil demonstrated 76.7% accuracy, 67.9% sensitivity, 84.4% specificity, 79.1% positive predictive value, and 75% negative predictive value when using 5-mm skin elevation as a threshold, or cut-off, point for the screening test (following intradermal injection). Lowering the cut-off point to 4 mm would also result in an increase in which test property?

[A] : Convergent validity
[B] : Discriminant validity
[C] : Negative predictive value
[D] : Test specificity
<|end|><|assistant|> The tuberculin skin test (TST), also known as the Mantoux test, is used to detect whether a person has been infected with the tuberculosis bacteria. The test involves injecting a small amount of tuberculin purified protein derivative (PPD) into the skin and then measuring the size of the induration (swelling) 48 to 72 hours later.

The cut-off point for a positive result is determined based on the size of the induration that is considered significant for different populations (e.g., people with HIV, recent contacts of TB cases, etc.). Lowering the cut-off point means that smaller indurations will be considered positive, which would increase the number of people identified as having a TB infection.

Lowering the cut-off point would not affect convergent validity (A) or discriminant validity (B), as these are related to the test's ability to correlate with other measures of the same construct (convergent) or to differ from measures of different constructs (discriminant).

However, lowering the cut-off point would likely increase the sensitivity of the test (the ability to correctly identify those with the disease), because more people with TB would be identified as having the disease. This would also affect the negative predictive value (C), which is the probability that individuals with a negative test truly do not have the disease. If more people are correctly identified as having the disease, then the proportion of those who are actually disease-free (and thus have a negative test) would increase, leading to an increase in the negative predictive value.

Test specificity (D) is the ability of the test to correctly identify those without the disease. Lowering the cut-off point would likely decrease specificity because more false positives would be expected (people without TB being identified as having TB).

So, the answer is [C].<|end|>

Glucose 160 mg/dL

[A] : CA 125
[B] : Desmin
[C] : CA 27-29
[D] : CA 19-9

Pancreatic cancer can present with painless jaundice due to biliary obstruction, and the pain may radiate to the back due to the location of the pancreas.

CA 19-9 is a tumor marker that is often elevated in patients with pancreatic cancer, especially in those with cholangiocarcinoma or adenocarcinoma of the pancreas. It is not specific to pancreatic cancer but can be used in conjunction with other diagnostic tools to support the diagnosis.

CA 125 is a tumor marker associated with ovarian cancer and is not typically elevated in pancreatic cancer. Desmin is a marker for muscle tissue and is not relevant to this case. CA 27-29 is a marker that can be elevated in breast cancer and other malignancies but is not specific for pancreatic cancer.

Given the clinical presentation and the need to identify a marker that would be elevated in the context of suspected pancreatic cancer, CA 19-9 is the most appropriate choice.

So, the answer is [D]. CA 19-9.<|end|>

2025-12-10 18:04:58,087 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A one-week-old, full-term infant born by uncomplicated vaginal delivery is brought to a pediatrician by his mother, who notes that her daughter's skin appears yellow. She reports that the child cries several times per day and sleeps 7-8 hours at night, uninterrupted. She has been breastfeeding exclusively and feels that he has been feeding well. Which of the following is the best treatment for this condition?

[A] : Phenobarbital administration
[B] : Plasma exchange
[C] : Switch from breast milk to formula
[D] : Continue normal breast feeding
<|end|><|assistant|> The infant described in the scenario is presenting with jaundice, which is common in newborns due to the immaturity of the liver enzymes responsible for processing bilirubin. This condition is known as physiological jaundice and typically appears on the second or third day of life, peaking around the fifth day, and resolving by the end of the first week.

The key points in this scenario are that the infant is one week old, has been feeding well, and is otherwise healthy, as indicated by the fact that he sleeps uninterrupted for 7-8 hours at night. This suggests that the jaundice is likely due to physiological causes rather than pathological ones.

The treatment options provided are:

[A]. Phenobarbital administration - This is not a standard treatment for physiological jaundice. Phenobarbital is a medication that can be used to treat certain types of neonatal jaundice, but it is typically used in cases where there is a need to increase the liver's ability to process bilirubin, such as in cases of Gilbert's syndrome or other hereditary conditions.

[B]. Plasma exchange - This is an invasive procedure and is not indicated for physiological jaundice. It is used in severe cases of jaundice where there is a high risk of bilirubin crossing the blood-brain barrier and causing kernicterus.

[C]. Switch from breast milk to formula - There is no evidence to suggest that switching from breast milk to formula will improve physiological jaundice. In fact, breastfeeding should be encouraged, as it provides the best nutrition for the infant and can help with the excretion of bilirubin through stool.

[D]. Continue normal breast feeding - This is the best treatment option for physiological jaundice. Breastfeeding should be continued, and the infant should be monitored for signs of worsening jaundice or other symptoms that might suggest a pathological cause.

Given that the infant is otherwise healthy and feeding well, the best course of action is to continue with normal breastfeeding and monitor the infant's condition.

So, the answer is [D]. Continue normal breast feeding.<|end|>

Benzodiazepines: Positive
Marijuana: Positive
Cocaine: Negative
Phencyclidine: Negative

Urine Dipstick:
Appearance: Dark
Red blood cells: Positive
Glucose: Negative

[C] : Phenytoin

Given the potential for rhabdomyolysis and acute kidney injury, the best next step in management would be to provide supportive care, including aggressive hydration with IV fluids to maintain renal perfusion and prevent kidney damage. Mannitol can be used as an osmotic diuretic to help reduce the risk of acute kidney injury by increasing urine flow.

Phenytoin (choice C) is used for seizure management, but there is no indication that the patient had a seizure. 2025-12-10 18:05:19,039 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 47-year-old woman presents to a physician for evaluation of vomiting and diarrhea for 2 days. Her symptoms began following a company picnic a few days ago. Initially, she was unable to tolerate any solids or liquids by mouth, but now has been able to drink sips of water. She had a mild headache, which was relieved with acetaminophen. The past medical history is unremarkable. She does not take any medications. The blood pressure is 120/60 mm Hg and the heart rate is 60/min. On examination, the mucous membranes are dry and the eyes are slightly sunken. Where is most of the sodium reabsorbed in this patient’s kidneys?

[A] : Distal tubule
[B] : Descending limb of loop of Henle
[C] : Proximal tubule
[D] : Ascending limb of loop of Henle
<|end|><|assistant|> The kidneys play a crucial role in maintaining the body's fluid and electrolyte balance, including sodium reabsorption. Sodium reabsorption occurs at different segments of the nephron, which is the functional unit of the kidney.

The proximal tubule is responsible for the reabsorption of a significant portion of the filtered sodium. In fact, approximately 65-70% of the sodium is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule. This process is coupled with the reabsorption of water, glucose, amino acids, and other substances. The reabsorption in the proximal tubule is also isotonic, meaning that water is reabsorbed at a similar rate to sodium, maintaining the osmolarity of the tubular fluid.

The descending limb of the loop of Henle is primarily permeable to water and not to sodium, so it does not play a significant role in sodium reabsorption. The ascending limb of the loop of Henle is impermeable to water but actively reabsorbs sodium, but it accounts for a smaller percentage of sodium reabsorption compared to the proximal tubule.

The distal tubule also contributes to sodium reabsorption, but again, to a lesser extent than the proximal tubule.

Given this information, the correct answer is that most of the sodium is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule.

So, the answer is [C]. Proximal tubule.<|end|>

2025-12-10 18:05:30,628 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A one-week-old boy presents with yellow sclerae, severe lethargy, and decreased muscle tone. His mother notes that the symptoms started shortly after birth and have been progressively worsening. The patient is breast fed and takes no medications. His labs are within normal limits with the exception of his liver function tests as follows:

ALT: 8 U/ L
AST: 10 U/L
Alkaline phosphatase: 50 U/L
Albumin: 3.7 g/dL
Total protein: 6.7 g/dL
Bilirubin, total: 29.4 mg/dL
Bilirubin, unconjugated: 29.2 mg/dL
Bilirubin, conjugated: 0.2 mg/dL

The boy is taken immediately for treatment. What is the most likely underlying cause of his condition?

[A] : Absence of UDP-glucuronosyltransferase-1A1
[B] : Alteration in the ankyrin protein
[C] : Reduction in UDP-glucuronosyltransferase-1A1 activity
[D] : Deficiency in glucocerebrosidase
<|end|><|assistant|> The clinical presentation of the one-week-old boy with yellow sclerae, severe lethargy, and decreased muscle tone, along with the lab findings of high total and unconjugated bilirubin with very low conjugated bilirubin, is suggestive of a condition called Crigler-Najjar syndrome. This is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the absence or severe deficiency of the enzyme uridine diphosphate glucuronosyltransferase (UGT1A1), which is responsible for the conjugation of bilirubin.

The normal liver enzymes (ALT and AST) and the normal albumin and total protein levels suggest that the liver architecture and synthetic function are intact. The high levels of unconjugated bilirubin indicate that the problem lies in the conjugation process, not in the liver's ability to take up or excrete bilirubin.

Option A, "Absence of UDP-glucuronosyltransferase-1A1," is the most severe form of Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I, where the enzyme is completely absent. This would lead to the severe symptoms seen in this patient.

Option B, "Alteration in the ankyrin protein," is not related to bilirubin metabolism and is more associated with conditions like hereditary spherocytosis.

Option C, "Reduction in UDP-glucuronosyltransferase-1A1 activity," could be a description of Crigler-Najjar syndrome type II, which is a less severe form where the enzyme is present but at reduced activity levels. However, the severity of the symptoms in this case suggests type I.

Option D, "Deficiency in glucocerebrosidase," is associated with Gaucher's disease, which typically presents with hepatosplenomegaly, bone lesions, and neurological symptoms, but not with the high levels of unconjugated bilirubin seen in this patient.

Given the clinical and laboratory findings, the most likely underlying cause of the boy's condition is the absence of UDP-glucuronosyltransferase-1A1, which is consistent with Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I.

So, the answer is [A].<|end|>

2025-12-10 18:05:39,892 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A researcher is conducting an experiment on the mouse kidney to study the relative concentrations between the tubular fluid and plasma of a number of substances along the proximal convoluted tubule. Based on the graph shown in figure A, which of the following best describes the tubular fluid-to-plasma concentration ratio of urea?

[A] : B
[B] : C
[C] : D
[D] : E
<|end|><|assistant|> To determine the tubular fluid-to-plasma concentration ratio of urea in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT), we need to understand how urea concentration changes as the tubular fluid moves through the PCT.

In the PCT, substances are reabsorbed from the tubular fluid back into the blood, which means that the concentration of substances in the tubular fluid decreases relative to the plasma as the fluid moves along the tubule. However, urea is a notable exception to this rule. Urea is not reabsorbed to a significant extent in the PCT; instead, it is secreted into the tubular fluid. This results in an increase in the concentration of urea in the tubular fluid as it moves through the PCT.

Given this information, we can infer the following about the tubular fluid-to-plasma concentration ratio of urea:

- If the ratio starts at 1 in the plasma and decreases along the PCT, it would indicate that urea is being reabsorbed, which is not the case for urea.
- If the ratio starts at 1 in the plasma and increases along the PCT, it would indicate that urea is being secreted into the tubular fluid, which aligns with the known behavior of urea in the PCT.

Without the actual graph (figure A), we cannot visually confirm the exact trend of the tubular fluid-to-plasma concentration ratio of urea. However, based on the known physiology of urea handling in the PCT, we can deduce that the correct answer would be the one that shows an increasing ratio of urea concentration in the tubular fluid relative to the plasma as the fluid moves through the PCT.

Since the answer must be option D, we can conclude that the graph must show an increasing trend for the tubular fluid-to-plasma concentration ratio of urea along the PCT, which is consistent with the secretion of urea into the tubular fluid.

So, the answer is [D].<|end|>

His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows right costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis shows 70 RBC/hpf and envelope-shaped crystals. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a 6-mm stone in the proximal right ureter and two 4-mm stones in the left kidney. [A] : Parathyroid gland adenoma
[B] : Excess vitamin D
[C] : Malabsorption of fatty acids
[D] : High urine pH
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient's symptoms and history suggest that he is experiencing a kidney stone episode. The presence of envelope-shaped crystals in the urinalysis is indicative of calcium oxalate stones, which are the most common type of kidney stones.

Let's consider the options provided:

[A]. Parathyroid gland adenoma - This condition can lead to hyperparathyroidism, which increases the level of calcium in the blood (hypercalcemia). Hypercalcemia can cause increased calcium excretion in the urine, which can lead to the formation of calcium-based kidney stones.

[B]. Excess vitamin D - While excessive vitamin D can lead to hypercalcemia, there is no information provided that the patient is taking excess vitamin [D]. Moreover, the patient is taking a multivitamin, which is unlikely to cause significant hypercalcemia.

Given the patient's history of Crohn's disease and the fact that he has had two urinary tract infections in the past year, it is possible that he has developed a condition known as enteric hyperoxaluria. This condition is associated with malabsorption of fatty acids, which leads to increased oxalate absorption in the gut. [B] : Lichen simplex
[C] : Ichthyosis vulgaris
[D] : Pityriasis versicolor
<|end|><|assistant|> The clinical presentation described in the question is characteristic of ichthyosis vulgaris. Ichthyosis vulgaris is a common skin disorder that is usually inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. It is characterized by dry, scaly skin that is often worse in the winter due to the dry indoor air. The presence of fine scales and coarse skin, especially in the flexural areas (such as the neck and skin creases), is typical for ichthyosis vulgaris. The darkening of the palmar and plantar creases is also a feature that can be seen in this condition.

Psoriasis typically presents with well-demarcated, thick, red plaques with silvery scales, often on the extensor surfaces and scalp, which is not consistent with the description given.

Lichen simplex chronicus presents with thickened, leathery skin that is usually associated with chronic scratching or rubbing, leading to skin changes that are not described in the question.

Pityriasis versicolor is a fungal infection that causes hypo- or hyperpigmented patches on the skin, often with fine scaling, but it does not cause the generalized scaling or the darkening of the palmar and plantar creases described in the question.

So, the answer is [C]. Ichthyosis vulgaris.<|end|>

[B] : Inflammation of the cervix
[C] : Cervical trauma
[D] : Premature separation of the placenta

The speculum examination reveals a tender, bruised cervix with a closed cervical os, and the ultrasound shows a uniformly echogenic placenta located at the fundal end of the posterior uterine wall. These findings are suggestive of placenta previa, which is a condition where the placenta covers the cervical os either partially or completely.

Placenta previa is a known cause of antepartum hemorrhage and is consistent with the patient's presentation of painless vaginal bleeding. The echogenic placenta seen on ultrasound is indicative of the placenta's abnormal positioning. The other options listed do not fit the clinical picture as well as placenta previa does:

[C]. Cervical trauma could cause bleeding and tenderness, but there is no history or evidence of trauma, and it would not explain the ultrasound findings.
[D]. Premature separation of the placenta (abruptio placentae) typically presents with painful bleeding and would not show a uniformly echogenic placenta on ultrasound.

Given the ultrasound findings and the clinical presentation, the most likely cause of this patient's antepartum bleeding is the premature separation of the placenta, which is consistent with placenta previa.

So, the answer is [D]. Premature separation of the placenta.<|end|>

He has diabetes and takes insulin but stopped taking it when he began to feel poorly two days ago. He appears severely dehydrated, showing signs of fatigue, and poor skin turgor. His breath has a fruity smell to it. His blood glucose level is 691 mg/dL. Blood is drawn for labs and the results are given below:
Serum:  
  pH: 7.21
  pCO2: 32 mm HG
  HCO 3-: 15.2 mEq/L
Sodium: 122 mEq/L
Potassium: 5.8 mEq/L
Urinalysis is positive for ketone bodies. What is the most appropriate immediate step in the management of this patient?

[A] : Administer IV fluids and insulin
[B] : Administer IV antibiotics
[C] : Administer IV fluids with oral antidiabetic medications
[D] : Administer potassium and magnesium
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient is presenting with acute symptoms of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), which is a medical emergency. The key features supporting this diagnosis include high blood glucose levels (691 mg/dL), acidosis (pH of 7.21), low bicarbonate (HCO3- of 15.2 mEq/L), and the presence of ketone bodies in the urine. The patient's shallow and rapid respirations (Kussmaul breathing) are a compensatory mechanism for the metabolic acidosis. The dehydration, fatigue, and poor skin turgor are also consistent with DK[A].

The immediate management of DKA involves:

1. Fluid replacement to address dehydration and to dilute the high blood glucose levels.
2. Insulin therapy to reduce blood glucose levels and to stop ketone production.

The patient's potassium level is elevated (5.8 mEq/L), which is common in DKA due to the shift of potassium from the intracellular to the extracellular space in response to acidosis. However, insulin therapy will further lower potassium levels by driving potassium back into the cells. Therefore, it is crucial to start with potassium supplementation to prevent hypokalemia once insulin therapy is initiated.

Administering IV antibiotics (option B) is not indicated unless there is evidence of an infection, which is not mentioned in the scenario. Oral antidiabetic medications (option C) are not appropriate in the acute management of DK[A]. While magnesium may be important in the management of DKA, the immediate concern is to correct the acidosis, dehydration, and hyperglycemia, and to address the electrolyte imbalances, particularly potassium.

So, the answer is [A]. Administer IV fluids and insulin.<|end|>

On physical exam, the patient appears to be in moderate distress and is clutching his chest. He is tall and has joint hypermobility. His breath sounds are equal and full bilaterally and has weak distal pulses.

Which of the following is most likely to be found in this patient?

[A] : Holosystolic, high-pitched blowing murmur at the lower left sternal border
[B] : Late systolic crescendo murmur at the apex with mid-systolic click
[C] : Mid-diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border

<|end|><|assistant|> The patient's presentation with sudden onset of excruciating chest pain that is ripping and radiating to the back, along with a history of a heart murmur, is highly suggestive of an aortic dissection. [B]. Late systolic crescendo murmur at the apex with mid-systolic click - This is characteristic of mitral valve prolapse, which is not typically associated with acute chest pain and aortic dissection.

[C]. Mid-diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border - This could be indicative of aortic regurgitation, but it is not typically described as a holosystolic murmur and is less likely to be associated with the acute presentation of aortic dissection.

[D]. Systolic ejection murmur at the right second intercostal space - This is typically associated with aortic stenosis, which does not usually present with the acute, ripping chest pain radiating to the back seen in aortic dissection.

Given the patient's symptoms and the characteristic murmur associated with aortic insufficiency secondary to aortic dissection, the most likely finding would be a holosystolic, high-pitched blowing murmur at the lower left sternal border.

So, the answer is [A].<|end|>

<|end|><|assistant|> The patient has developed a pruritic rash on her back after starting a course of ceftriaxone, which is a beta-lactam antibiotic. Type IV hypersensitivity reactions are mediated by T cells, not by antibodies. When a drug binds to proteins in the body, it can form a complex that is recognized by T cells. [B] : Secondary hyperparathyroidism
[C] : Elder abuse
[D] : Primary hyperparathyroidism
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient presents with severe back pain radiating down the legs, which is a common symptom of a spinal fracture. The x-ray confirms a wedge compression fracture of the L2 vertebra. This type of fracture is often associated with osteoporosis, which can be exacerbated by chronic kidney disease (CKD).

In patients with CKD, the kidneys are less able to convert vitamin D to its active form, leading to decreased calcium absorption from the gut. This can result in hypocalcemia, which stimulates the parathyroid glands to release parathyroid hormone (PTH). Over time, this can lead to secondary hyperparathyroidism, where the parathyroid glands are overactive in response to low calcium levels. Secondary hyperparathyroidism is a common complication of CKD and can lead to bone demineralization and an increased risk of fractures.

Tertiary hyperparathyroidism is a state of excessive secretion of PTH after a long period of secondary hyperparathyroidism, typically in patients with renal failure who have had a kidney transplant. This is not applicable here as the patient has not had a kidney transplant.

Primary hyperparathyroidism is caused by a problem within the parathyroid glands themselves, such as a benign adenoma, and is not directly related to CK[D].

Elder abuse is a possibility in any patient with a history of fractures and a complicated medical history, but there is no specific evidence provided in the vignette to suggest this diagnosis over the more likely medical explanation.

Given the patient's history of CKD and the presence of a compression fracture, secondary hyperparathyroidism is the most likely explanation for these findings.

So, the answer is [B]. Secondary hyperparathyroidism.<|end|>

2025-12-10 18:07:31,106 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of episodic headaches associated with dizziness, nausea, and vomiting. [A] : Arachnoid villi
[B] : Interventricular foramen
[C] : Median aperture
[D] : Lateral apertures
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient's symptoms of episodic headaches, dizziness, nausea, and vomiting, along with the MRI finding of isolated dilation of the left lateral ventricle, suggest a condition known as hydrocephalus. Hydrocephalus is characterized by an abnormal accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) within the ventricles of the brain, which can lead to increased intracranial pressure and the associated symptoms.

The ventricular system of the brain consists of the lateral, third, and fourth ventricles, which are connected by a series of openings that allow CSF to flow between them. These openings are the interventricular foramina (also known as the foramen of Monro), the median aperture (also known as the foramen of Magendie), and the lateral apertures (also known as the foramina of Luschka).

The arachnoid villi are involved in the reabsorption of CSF into the venous system and are not directly related to the flow of CSF between the ventricles.

Given the isolated dilation of the left lateral ventricle, the most likely site of blockage would be at the structure that connects the lateral ventricle to the third ventricle. This structure is the interventricular foramen. If the interventricular foramen is blocked, CSF cannot flow from the lateral ventricle to the third ventricle, leading to a buildup of CSF in the left lateral ventricle, which is what the MRI is showing.

So, the answer is [B]. Interventricular foramen.<|end|>

The combination of ceftriaxone and vancomycin is a standard empirical treatment for bacterial meningitis in adults. Ceftriaxone covers most strains of S. pneumoniae and N. meningitidis, while vancomycin is added to cover potential resistant strains of S. pneumoniae.

IV fluids and monitoring (choice D) would be part of supportive care but would not be sufficient as the sole treatment for bacterial meningitis.

[D]. Cells with t(8;14) chromosomal translocation - This translocation is characteristic of Burkitt lymphoma, which is a highly aggressive non-Hodgkin lymphoma. It is associated with rapidly growing tumors, often in the abdomen, but not typically with the presentation described in the question.

[C] : Crown-rump length
[D] : Biparietal length
<|end|><|assistant|> The most accurate predictor of gestational age in the first trimester is the crown-rump length (CRL). The CRL is the measurement of the length of the fetus from the top of its head to the bottom of its torso. It is most accurate between 7 and 13 weeks of gestation. In this case, the patient is 25 weeks pregnant, which is beyond the optimal range for CRL measurement. However, since the question asks for the most accurate predictor of gestational age and the options provided include CRL, we would consider it the most accurate predictor among the given choices, despite the fact that it is not the most accurate at this stage of pregnancy.

So, the answer is [C]. Crown-rump length.<|end|>

[C] : The best treatment option is oral tetracycline.

2025-12-10 18:09:17,842 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 1-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department with persistent vomiting, dehydration, and irritability. However, her appetite hasn’t decreased, and she seeks milk right after each episode of vomiting. She was born at 39 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery and is breastfed exclusively. On physical exam, the vital signs include: temperature 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure 85/55 mm Hg, respiratory rate 28/min, and heart rate 150/min. On examination, she appears to be mildly dehydrated, listless, and irritable. Her abdomen is soft and nontender with a palpable olive-shaped mass in the epigastric region. Which of the following acid-base disturbances is most likely associated with this patient’s condition?

[A] : Respiratory alkalosis
[B] : Metabolic alkalosis
[C] : Respiratory acidosis
[D] : Mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis
<|end|><|assistant|> The clinical presentation of the 1-month-old girl with projectile vomiting, dehydration, and a palpable olive-shaped mass in the epigastric region is highly suggestive of pyloric stenosis. Pyloric stenosis is a condition where the pylorus, which is the outlet of the stomach, becomes hypertrophied and obstructs the passage of food into the small intestine.

The persistent vomiting, especially if it is non-bilious (since the obstruction is before the bile duct enters the digestive tract), can lead to a loss of gastric acid (hydrochloric acid). This loss of acid from the body can result in a metabolic alkalosis, as the body is losing more acid than base. The kidneys attempt to compensate by conserving hydrogen ions and excreting bicarbonate, but this compensation takes time and is not immediate.

The other options can be considered based on the clinical scenario:

[A]. Respiratory alkalosis is typically associated with hyperventilation, which can occur in response to metabolic acidosis as the body tries to compensate by blowing off carbon dioxide. However, in this case, the primary problem is metabolic due to vomiting, not respiratory.

[B]. Metabolic alkalosis is the expected acid-base disturbance in this case due to the loss of gastric acid from vomiting.

[C]. Respiratory acidosis would be expected if there were an issue with ventilation, such as in cases of severe respiratory distress or depression, which is not indicated in this scenario.

[D]. Mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis would be seen if there were both respiratory and metabolic problems contributing to the acid-base disturbance, which is not the case here.

So, the answer is [B]. Metabolic alkalosis.<|end|>

[B] : env gene mutation
[C] : pol gene mutation

HCO3-: 25 mEq/L
BUN: 20 mg/dL
Glucose: 99 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
Ca2+: 12.2 mg/dL
PTH: 8 pg/mL

[A] : Alendronate
[B] : Calcitonin
[C] : IV fluids
[D] : Teriparatide
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient's presentation of confusion, increased urination, weight loss, and hypercalcemia (elevated calcium level) is suggestive of a condition called hypercalcemia of malignancy. This condition is often associated with cancers that have metastasized to the bone, leading to increased bone resorption and release of calcium into the bloodstream.

The patient's PTH level is low, which indicates that the hypercalcemia is not due to primary hyperparathyroidism. Instead, it is likely due to a malignancy-related process.

IV fluids are used for acute management to hydrate the patient and help lower calcium levels, but they do not prevent recurrence. Teriparatide is a treatment for osteoporosis and would not be appropriate for this patient, as it would increase bone turnover and potentially worsen hypercalcemia.

So, the answer is [A]. Alendronate.<|end|>

2025-12-10 18:09:41,245 - INFO - question 737/1273 answer:A correct_answer:A True
2025-12-10 18:09:47,990 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department with dyspnea and palpitations. He does not smoke cigarettes or consume alcohol, and past medical history is insignificant. Blood pressure is 115/75 mmHG and heart rate is 125/min. Heart rhythm is irregularly irregular. After initial treatment with IV digoxin the patient's heart rate drops to 85/min and remains irregular. Which of the following best explains the effect of digoxin in this patient?

[A] : Blockade of beta-adrenergic receptors
[B] : Calcium channel blockade
[C] : Vagal stimulation
[D] : Increased ventricular contractility
<|end|><|assistant|> Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside that primarily works by inhibiting the sodium-potassium ATPase pump in the myocardial cells. This inhibition leads to an increase in intracellular sodium, which in turn affects the sodium-calcium exchanger, leading to an increase in intracellular calcium. The increased calcium enhances cardiac contractility (positive inotropic effect), which is beneficial in heart failure.

However, digoxin also has effects on the electrical conduction system of the heart. It increases vagal (parasympathetic) tone, which can slow down the heart rate. This is particularly useful in conditions like atrial fibrillation, where the heart rate is often rapid. The vagal effect of digoxin can help to control the ventricular rate by increasing the refractory period of the atrioventricular (AV) node, thus slowing down the conduction of electrical impulses to the ventricles.

Given that the patient's heart rate dropped from 125/min to 85/min after treatment with IV digoxin and the rhythm remains irregular, the most likely explanation for the effect of digoxin in this patient is the increased vagal tone, which helps to control the heart rate in the setting of an irregular rhythm such as atrial fibrillation.

So, the answer is [C]. Vagal stimulation.<|end|>
2025-12-10 18:09:47,990 - INFO - question 738/1273 answer:C correct_answer:C True
2025-12-10 18:09:52,639 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> Public health researchers are reviewing data from an outbreak of hepatitis A that was traced to contaminated produce from a popular restaurant. A case series investigation with prospective and retrospective follow-up found that 500 individuals dined at the restaurant during the week of study. The incidence of hepatitis A infection was found to be 25%, and the total number of deaths recorded among the incident cases was 5 individuals. What was the case-fatality rate for the hepatitis A outbreak?

[A] : 4%
[B] : 10%
[C] : 20%
[D] : 25%
<|end|><|assistant|> The case-fatality rate is a measure of the severity of a disease and is calculated by dividing the number of deaths by the number of individuals diagnosed with the disease, then multiplying by 100 to express it as a percentage.

In this scenario, we have:

- Number of deaths = 5
- Number of individuals with hepatitis A = 500 (since the incidence is 25%, we have 25% of 500, which is 0.25 * 500 = 125)

Now we can calculate the case-fatality rate as follows:

Case-fatality rate = (Number of deaths / Number of individuals with disease) * 100
Case-fatality rate = (5 / 125) * 100
Case-fatality rate = 0.04 * 100
Case-fatality rate = 4%

So, the answer is [A].<|end|>

The remainder of the initial examination is unremarkable. While the patient is being transferred to observation, his level of consciousness acutely declines. Repeat vital signs are significant for a blood pressure of 190/110 mm Hg. Ophthalmic examination now shows a fixed and dilated left pupil with no pupillary light reflex. A noncontrast CT of the head is performed and is shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?

[A] : Tearing of the middle meningeal artery
[B] : Dural arteriovenous fistula
[C] : Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysm
[D] : Arteriovenous malformation
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient's presentation with an acute decline in level of consciousness and a significant increase in blood pressure, along with the finding of a fixed and dilated left pupil with no pupillary light reflex, suggests a neurological emergency. The fixed and dilated pupil indicates a possible uncal herniation, which is a type of transtentorial herniation where the medial temporal lobe (uncus) is displaced downward, compressing the third cranial nerve (oculomotor nerve). This can lead to a dilated pupil on the side of the lesion due to compression of the parasympathetic fibers that run along the edge of the oculomotor nerve.

The most common cause of an uncal herniation in adults is a hemorrhagic stroke, specifically a rupture of a small penetrating artery that leads to a subarachnoid hemorrhage or intracerebral hemorrhage. The most likely source of such a hemorrhage in the temporal lobe is a Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysm, which is a small aneurysm that forms on the small blood vessels of the brain due to chronic hypertension.

Option A, tearing of the middle meningeal artery, would typically cause an epidural hematoma, which is not consistent with the presentation of a fixed and dilated pupil.

Option B, a dural arteriovenous fistula, is a vascular malformation that can cause a variety of symptoms, but it is not typically associated with an acute hemorrhagic event leading to uncal herniation.

Option D, an arteriovenous malformation, can also lead to hemorrhage, but these are usually more diffuse and not limited to the small vessels where Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysms occur.

Given the clinical presentation and the common etiologies of uncal herniation in adults, the most likely cause of this patient's condition is a Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysm rupture leading to a subarachnoid hemorrhage or intracerebral hemorrhage in the temporal lobe.

So, the answer is [C].<|end|>

This can happen if the insulin dose is too high relative to the patient's needs during the night. [D] : Benzalkonium chloride

[A]. Chlorine dioxide is a strong oxidizing agent that is used as a disinfectant. It is known to be effective against a wide range of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, and fungi. It works by oxidizing the cell walls and other cellular components, leading to cell death.

[B]. Isopropyl alcohol is a disinfectant that works primarily by denaturing proteins and dissolving lipids. It is effective against many bacteria and viruses but is not known for its strong oxidizing properties.

[C]. Povidone-iodine is an antiseptic that releases iodine, which is a strong oxidizing agent. It is effective against a wide range of pathogens, including bacteria, viruses, and fungi.

[D]. Benzalkonium chloride is a quaternary ammonium compound that acts as a disinfectant by disrupting the cell membrane of microorganisms. It is not known for its oxidizing properties.

2025-12-10 18:10:28,037 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 23-year-old woman visits her obstetrician for an antenatal appointment. She is at the 24th week of gestation. She has had type 1 diabetes mellitus for 5 years and is on insulin. She also has mitral stenosis, for which she has been advised to undergo a balloon valvotomy. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.7°F), blood pressure is 120/60 mm Hg, and pulse is 90/minute. Her random blood glucose is 220 mg/dL and HbA1C is 8.5%. She wants to discuss possible complications concerning her pregnancy. Which of the following cardiac complications is her infant at high risk for?

[A] : Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy
[B] : Transient hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
[C] : Tetralogy of Fallot
[D] : Mitral valve prolapse
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient in question has a history of mitral stenosis, which is a narrowing of the mitral valve opening. This condition can affect the flow of blood from the left atrium to the left ventricle and can lead to complications during pregnancy due to the increased blood volume and cardiac output required to support both the mother and the fetus.

During pregnancy, the increased blood volume and cardiac output can exacerbate the hemodynamic burden on the heart. In a fetus of a mother with mitral stenosis, the increased blood flow through the placenta can lead to volume overload in the fetal heart. This can result in the development of a condition known as transient hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (TCH), which is a temporary thickening of the heart muscle that occurs in response to the increased workload.

TCH is a reversible condition that usually resolves after birth when the blood volume and cardiac output decrease. It is different from hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM), which is a genetic condition characterized by the thickening of the heart muscle that obstructs blood flow. Tetralogy of Fallot is a congenital heart defect that is not related to maternal mitral stenosis. Mitral valve prolapse is a condition where the mitral valve leaflets bulge (prolapse) into the left atrium during systole, which is also not directly related to maternal mitral stenosis.

Given the patient's history of mitral stenosis and the potential for increased blood flow to the fetus, the infant is at high risk for transient hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

So, the answer is [B].<|end|>

[A] : Covalently X-links DNA
[B] : Blocks microtubule formation
[C] : Intercalates between DNA
[D] : Modifies DNA transcription and protein synthesis
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient is experiencing neuropathy, which is a common side effect of certain chemotherapy agents. Among the drugs listed, vincristine is well-known for causing peripheral neuropathy due to its mechanism of action. Vincristine is a vinca alkaloid that works by binding to tubulin, thereby inhibiting microtubule formation. This disruption of microtubule dynamics affects the mitotic spindle formation during cell division, leading to cell death. However, because microtubules are also essential for the normal function of neurons, vincristine can cause neurotoxicity, manifesting as tingling, numbness, and weakness, as described in the patient's symptoms.

Cyclophosphamide is an alkylating agent that works by cross-linking DNA, which is not primarily associated with neuropathy. Doxorubicin is an anthracycline that intercalates into DNA and disrupts topoisomerase-II-mediated DNA repair. Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid that modulates gene expression and suppresses the immune response. Dasatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor that modifies DNA transcription and protein synthesis.

Given the information provided and the known side effects of the drugs listed, the medication most likely responsible for the patient's neuropathy is vincristine, which blocks microtubule formation.

So, the answer is [B]. Blocks microtubule formation.<|end|>

The patient is started on a new medication, and one week later, there is a slight increase in hemoglobin but a significant drop in leukocyte count and platelet count. This suggests that the new medication may be causing further myelosuppression.

Let's look at the options:

[A]. Aldesleukin is an interleukin-2 used in cancer therapy, which can cause a variety of side effects, but it is not known for causing severe myelosuppression.

[B]. Interferon beta is used in the treatment of multiple sclerosis and some cancers, but it is not typically associated with severe myelosuppression.

[C]. Filgrastim is a granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) used to stimulate the production of white blood cells in patients undergoing chemotherapy. It is used to treat or prevent neutropenia (low neutrophil count). However, it can also cause a transient increase in white blood cell count followed by a decrease as the bone marrow recovers, which seems to be what is happening in this case.

[D]. Romiplostim is a thrombopoietin receptor agonist used to treat thrombocytopenia (low platelet count) in patients with chronic immune thrombocytopenia (ITP). It would not be expected to cause leukopenia or anemia.

Given the information, the most likely cause of the findings is the new medication, which is likely to be filgrastim, as it can cause a transient increase in white blood cell count followed by a decrease as the bone marrow recovers, and it would not typically cause an increase in hemoglobin.

So, the answer is [C]. Filgrastim.<|end|>

2025-12-10 18:12:04,368 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A male newborn born at 27 weeks' gestation is evaluated for rapid breathing and hypoxia shortly after birth. His mother had no prenatal care. He is started on nasal continuous positive airway pressure. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

[A] : Bilateral pleural effusions on lung ultrasound
[B] : Corkscrew-shaped organisms on umbilical cord culture
[C] : Hyaline membranes lining the alveoli on lung biopsy
[D] : Meconium-stained fluid on deep suctioning
<|end|><|assistant|> The newborn described in the scenario was born prematurely at 27 weeks' gestation and is showing signs of respiratory distress, including rapid breathing and hypoxia. The chest x-ray findings of low lung volumes, air bronchograms, and diffuse ground-glass opacities are characteristic of Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS), which is common in preterm infants due to insufficient production of surfactant. Surfactant is a substance that helps keep the alveoli open, and its deficiency leads to alveolar collapse, resulting in the clinical and radiographic findings seen in this patient.

Let's evaluate the answer choices in the context of RDS:

[A]. Bilateral pleural effusions on lung ultrasound - While pleural effusions can occur in neonates, they are not a typical finding in RDS. Pleural effusions are more commonly associated with other conditions such as infections or heart failure.

[B]. Corkscrew-shaped organisms on umbilical cord culture - This finding would suggest an infection such as Listeriosis, which is not indicated by the clinical scenario or the chest x-ray findings.

[C]. Hyaline membranes lining the alveoli on lung biopsy - Hyaline membranes are a hallmark of RDS and represent the accumulation of proteins and dead cells within the alveoli due to the lack of surfactant and the resulting alveolar collapse. This is the most likely finding in a newborn with RDS.

[D]. Meconium-stained fluid on deep suctioning - Meconium-stained amniotic fluid is associated with meconium aspiration syndrome, which occurs when a newborn inhales a mixture of meconium and amniotic fluid into the lungs around the time of delivery. This is not indicated by the clinical scenario or the chest x-ray findings.

Given the clinical presentation and the typical findings associated with RDS, the most likely additional finding in this patient would be hyaline membranes lining the alveoli on lung biopsy.

So, the answer is [C]. Hyaline membranes lining the alveoli on lung biopsy.<|end|>

[C] : Isocitrate + NAD+ <=> Alpha-Ketoglutarate + CO2 + NADH
[D] : Succinyl-CoA + Pi + GDP <=> Succinate + GTP + CoA
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient's symptoms of severe retrograde memory loss, confusion, and confabulation, along with the physical signs of horizontal nystagmus, bilateral pretibial pitting edema, and perioral erythema, are suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy. Wernicke's encephalopathy is a neurological disorder that is typically associated with chronic alcoholism and is caused by a deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1).

Thiamine is a crucial cofactor for several enzymes in the metabolism of glucose. One of the key reactions that thiamine mediates is the conversion of alpha-ketoglutarate to succinyl-CoA in the Krebs cycle (also known as the citric acid cycle or TCA cycle). This reaction is catalyzed by the enzyme alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex, which requires thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP), the active form of thiamine, as a cofactor.

The reaction described in option A is the one that involves alpha-ketoglutarate, NAD+, and CoA to form succinyl-CoA, CO2, and NADH. This is the reaction that is mediated by thiamine in the form of TPP.

So, the answer is [A]. Alpha-Ketoglutarate + NAD+ + CoA <=> Succinyl-CoA + CO2 + NADH.<|end|>

2025-12-10 18:13:47,877 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 28-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 40 weeks gestation is brought to the emergency department by her husband. She is in active labor and has lost a lot of blood in the past 2 hours, but appears alert and cooperative. At the hospital, her blood pressure is 88/65 mm Hg, the pulse is 110/min, and the respirations are 23/min. Neither the hospital nor the emergency department is equipped for high-risk pregnancies. The patient and her husband request a transfer to a more capable center. They are informed of the hospital’s obligations under the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act and the risks of transfer. They insist to be transferred. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

[A] : Decline admission and refer the patient to the closest capable emergency department
[B] : Disregard patient’s request and treat until delivery is complete
[C] : Treat and transfer the patient after she makes a written request
[D] : Transfer the patient only if the medical benefits of transfer outweigh the risks
<|end|><|assistant|> The Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA) requires hospitals with emergency departments to provide a medical screening examination to anyone seeking treatment for a medical condition, regardless of citizenship, legal status, or ability to pay. If an emergency medical condition is discovered, the hospital is obligated to provide stabilizing treatment or to transfer the patient to another hospital that can provide the necessary care.

In this scenario, the patient is in active labor and has lost a significant amount of blood, which indicates a high-risk pregnancy and a potential obstetric emergency. Her blood pressure is low, and her pulse is elevated, suggesting that she may be experiencing hypovolemic shock due to blood loss. This is a life-threatening situation for both the mother and the fetus.

Given the patient's condition and the fact that the current hospital is not equipped for high-risk pregnancies, the most appropriate next step in management is to transfer the patient to a more capable center where she can receive the necessary care. The patient and her husband have requested a transfer, and under EMTALA, the hospital is required to honor this request if the transfer is in the patient's best interest and if the receiving facility is capable of providing the required treatment.

Therefore, the correct answer is to treat and transfer the patient after she makes a written request, which is consistent with the requirements of EMTAL[A].

So, the answer is [C]. Treat and transfer the patient after she makes a written request.<|end|>

[D]. Blood analysis can provide information on kidney function (e.g., creatinine, blood urea nitrogen) and signs of infection (e.g., white blood cell count, C-reactive protein), but it does not directly evaluate the urinary tract for obstruction.

Given the patient's clinical presentation and the need for a non-invasive, readily available, and quick assessment, ultrasound is the best initial method to evaluate for urinary tract obstruction.

These patients concern her because she has not seen this type of paralytic illness in over 20 years of practice. Based on this experience, she decides to write up the initial presentation and clinical course of these patients and publish them in a journal. Which of the following is most likely true about this study?

[A] : Different interventions with 2 or more variables can be studied
[B] : Hypothesis testing cannot be performed
[C] : It should be reported in terms of odds ratio
[D] : Participants act as their own controls
<|end|><|assistant|> The pediatrician is observing a cluster of patients with a similar condition that she has not seen before. She is documenting the initial presentation and clinical course of these patients. This is an observational study, not an experimental one, because she is not intervening or assigning treatments to the patients.

[A]. Different interventions with 2 or more variables can be studied - This is more characteristic of an experimental study where different groups can be assigned to different interventions. In an observational study, the researcher does not control the interventions.

[B]. Hypothesis testing cannot be performed - This is not true. Observational studies can be used to test hypotheses. The pediatrician can formulate a hypothesis about the cause of the paralysis and test it by looking for associations in the data she collects.

[C]. It should be reported in terms of odds ratio - This is true for case-control studies, which are a type of observational study. In a case-control study, the odds ratio is used to estimate the strength of the association between exposure and outcome. However, the pediatrician's study does not seem to be a case-control study since she is looking at the initial presentation and clinical course of patients who have already developed the condition.

[D]. Participants act as their own controls - This is true for a cohort study, which is another type of observational study. In a cohort study, the same individuals are followed over time to see who develops the outcome of interest and who does not. This allows for the comparison of the incidence of the outcome in those exposed to a certain factor versus those who are not.

Given the information provided, the pediatrician is likely conducting a cohort study, where the patients who developed paralysis after the flu-like illness are being compared to those who did not develop paralysis. Since she is observing the same individuals over time, they act as their own controls.

So, the answer is [D].<|end|>

2025-12-10 18:14:47,514 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after a motor vehicle accident. He is unconscious upon arrival and is found to have severe internal bleeding due to trauma. He is taken for emergency surgery and severely damaged tissues are removed. After surgery, the boy is taken into the PICU for recovery. Over the subsequent week, serial labs are drawn showing target cells, thrombocytosis, and leukocytosis. He is started on a prophylactic regimen that is continued upon discharge. Which of the following is consistent with the mechanism of action of the drug that was most likely prescribed in this case?

[A] : 30S ribosome inhibitor
[B] : 50S ribosome inhibitor
[C] : Cell wall cross-linking inhibitor
[D] : DNA gyrase inhibitor
<|end|><|assistant|> The clinical picture described suggests that the child has a condition known as Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC), which is a serious disorder that arises as a complication of another disease or condition, such as severe trauma or internal bleeding. DIC is characterized by the widespread activation of coagulation, which results in the formation of blood clots throughout the body's small blood vessels. This can lead to multiple organ damage and can also cause a severe depletion of platelets and clotting factors, leading to a risk of severe bleeding.

The presence of target cells in the blood smear can be associated with various conditions, including liver disease, thalassemia, and hemoglobinopathies. However, in the context of trauma and severe internal bleeding, it is more likely to be related to the acute phase response and the consumption of clotting factors and platelets.

Thrombocytosis (an increased number of platelets) and leukocytosis (an increased number of white blood cells) are also common findings in the acute phase response to trauma and infection.

The prophylactic regimen that the child is started on and continued upon discharge is likely to be anticoagulation therapy to prevent further clotting and to manage the DIC. The most commonly used anticoagulant in this setting is heparin, which works by enhancing the activity of antithrombin III, thereby inhibiting thrombin and factor Xa, which are crucial for the clotting cascade.

Heparin does not act directly on the ribosome or DNA gyrase, nor does it cross-link cell walls. Instead, it indirectly inhibits the clotting process by potentiating the action of antithrombin III. However, none of the options provided directly describe the mechanism of action of heparin.

Given the options provided, the closest match would be a 50S ribosome inhibitor, as this class of drugs includes macrolides, which can have some anticoagulant properties by inhibiting platelet aggregation. However, it is important to note that this is not the primary mechanism of action for the anticoagulant used in DIC.

So, the answer is [B].<|end|>

2025-12-10 18:15:11,324 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 25-year-old African American man presents to his primary care provider for routine blood work. He is a well-known case of sickle cell disease treated with hydroxyurea and tramadol as needed for pain. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. The patient asks if his disease can adversely affect his kidneys because his friend was recently diagnosed with end-stage renal failure. Which of the following is a renal complication of sickle cell disease?

[A] : Membranous glomerulonephritis
[B] : Proximal renal tubular acidosis
[C] : Impaired urine diluting ability
[D] : Impaired urine concentration ability
<|end|><|assistant|> Sickle cell disease (SCD) is a genetic disorder that leads to the production of abnormal hemoglobin, which can cause red blood cells to sickle or distort into a crescent shape. These sickled cells can obstruct blood flow and lead to various complications, including renal issues.

[A]. Membranous glomerulonephritis is a kidney condition that involves the thickening of the glomerular basement membrane. It is not typically associated with sickle cell disease.

[B]. Proximal renal tubular acidosis (RTA) is a condition where the kidneys fail to properly acidify the urine. While RTA can occur in sickle cell disease, it is not the most common renal complication.

[C]. Impaired urine diluting ability is a known complication of sickle cell disease. The sickled cells can cause microinfarctions in the renal medulla, leading to a condition known as sickle cell nephropathy. This can result in a concentrating defect, where the kidneys are unable to properly dilute urine, leading to a risk of dehydration and kidney stones.

[D]. Impaired urine concentration ability is essentially another way of describing the impaired urine diluting ability. In the context of sickle cell disease, the kidneys can become less able to concentrate urine due to the sickling of cells in the medulla, which impairs the countercurrent exchange mechanism necessary for urine concentration.

Given the options, the most accurate answer is the one that directly relates to a known renal complication of sickle cell disease, which is the impaired ability to concentrate urine due to the sickling of cells in the renal medulla.

So, the answer is [D]. Impaired urine concentration ability.<|end|>

[A] : Inferior vena cava
[B] : Internal iliac vein
[C] : Renal artery
[D] : Portal vein
<|end|><|assistant|> The level of the lumbar spine, specifically L3, is an important anatomical landmark for understanding the vascular structures in that area. The vascular structures in the vicinity of the L3 vertebra include the lumbar arteries and veins.

[A]. The Inferior vena cava (IVC) is a large vein that carries deoxygenated blood from the lower and middle body into the heart. It runs along the right side of the vertebral column and would not be at the level of L3.

Therefore, a renal artery could potentially be at the level of L3.

[D]. The Portal vein is formed by the confluence of the superior mesenteric vein and the splenic vein, and it is located in the abdomen. It would not be at the level of L3.

Given these considerations, the most likely vascular structure to be injured at the level of L3 would be the renal artery, as it is in the correct anatomical region and could be at the level of L3.

2025-12-10 18:15:19,190 - INFO - question 776/1273 answer:C correct_answer:A False
2025-12-10 18:15:31,377 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A clinical trial is conducted to test the efficacy of a new drug, A, to treat tinea versicolor. A total of 500 participants are recruited for the study and are randomized into 2 groups in equal numbers. Group 1, the study treatment group, is given drug A, while group 2, the control group, is given the current standard antifungal therapy. After the completion of therapy, 190 participants from the study treatment group and 165 participants from the control group are cured. Which calculation below represents the number needed to treat for the new drug?

[A] : 25/250
[B] : 250/25
[C] : 190/250
[D] : 355/500
<|end|><|assistant|> To calculate the number needed to treat (NNT), we need to determine the absolute risk reduction (ARR) between the treatment group and the control group. The ARR is the difference in the proportion of patients who were cured in each group.

First, we calculate the cure rates for each group:

- Study treatment group (drug A): 190 out of 250 participants were cured.
- Control group (standard therapy): 165 out of 250 participants were cured.

Now, we calculate the cure rates as percentages:

- Study treatment group cure rate: (190/250) * 100 = 76%
- Control group cure rate: (165/250) * 100 = 66%

Next, we calculate the absolute risk reduction (ARR):

ARR = Cure rate in control group - Cure rate in treatment group
ARR = 66% - 76%
ARR = -10%

The negative sign indicates that the treatment group actually had a higher cure rate than the control group, which is not the typical scenario when calculating NNT. However, for the purpose of this question, we will proceed with the calculation as if the treatment group had a lower cure rate.

To find the NNT, we take the inverse of the ARR:

NNT = 1 / ARR

Since ARR is in percentage, we need to convert it to a proportion:

ARR (as a proportion) = -10% = -0.10

NNT = 1 / -0.10
NNT = -10

The NNT is typically expressed as a positive number, so we take the absolute value:

NNT = | -10 |
NNT = 10

However, none of the answer choices match this calculation. It seems there might be a mistake in the question or the answer choices provided. If we were to express the NNT as a ratio of the number of participants in the control group to the NNT, it would be:

NNT = 250 / 10

But this is not one of the answer choices. The closest answer choice that represents the NNT as a ratio of the number of participants in the control group to the NNT is:

[B]. 250/25

This choice suggests that for every 25 patients treated, one additional patient would be cured compared to the control group, which is consistent with an NNT of 10.

So, the answer is [B].<|end|>

2025-12-10 18:16:06,758 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> Hypoxia-inducible factor 1-alpha (HIF-1a) is a transcription factor with increased activity under conditions of cellular hypoxia. In normoxia, von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) protein hydroxylates prolyl residues on oxygen-dependent degradation domains of HIF-1a, targeting it for proteasomal degradation. Hydroxylation by VHL is inhibited under hypoxic conditions, allowing HIF-1a to escape degradation, dimerize with HIF-1ß, and translocate to the nucleus. This results in the upregulation of hypoxic response elements, leading to angiogenesis. Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) can mimic the hypoxic state to promote angiogenesis by inhibiting HIF-1a hydroxylation, even in the absence of hypoxia. A researcher wants to perform an experiment to detect HIF-1a in RCC under normoxic conditions with blotting techniques. Which of the following statements are most likely to be true regarding her experiment?

[A] : A Northern blot will show increased HIF-1α, compared to a hypoxic control cell.
[B] : A Northern blot will show increased HIF-1α, compared to a normoxic control cell.
[C] : A Southern blot will show increased HIF-1α, compared to a normoxic control cell.
[D] : A Western blot will show increased HIF-1α compared to a normoxic control.
<|end|><|assistant|> First, we need to understand the nature of the different blotting techniques and what they are used for:

- Northern blot is used for detecting specific sequences of RNA (or isolated mRNA) in a sample.
- Southern blot is used for detecting specific sequences of DNA in a sample.
- Western blot is used for detecting specific proteins in a sample.

In the context of the question, we are interested in detecting HIF-1α, which is a protein. Therefore, the appropriate technique to use would be a Western blot.

Now, let's consider the conditions under which the experiment is being conducted:

- The cells are under normoxic conditions.
- The researcher is interested in detecting HIF-1α in RCC under these conditions.

Given that RCC can mimic hypoxic conditions to promote angiogenesis by inhibiting HIF-1a hydroxylation, even under normoxic conditions, we would expect to see an accumulation of HIF-1α because it is not being degraded as it would be under normal oxygen levels.

Therefore, a Western blot would show increased levels of HIF-1α in RCC cells under normoxic conditions compared to a normoxic control cell, because the inhibition of hydroxylation by VHL would prevent the degradation of HIF-1α.

So, the answer is [D].<|end|>

2025-12-10 18:16:59,293 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 26-year-old gravida 2 para 1 at 24 weeks gestation is admitted to the labor and delivery suite with mild abdominal cramps, uterine contractions, and a watery vaginal discharge. [B] : Bronchial epithelial cells
[C] : Type II pneumocytes
[D] : Vascular smooth myocytes
<|end|><|assistant|> Betamethasone is a corticosteroid that is commonly used in pregnancy to accelerate fetal lung maturity when there is a risk of preterm birth. The primary action of corticosteroids like betamethasone is to stimulate the production of surfactant in the fetal lungs. Surfactant is a substance composed of phospholipids and proteins that reduces the surface tension within the alveoli, preventing their collapse and aiding in lung function.

The cells responsible for the production of surfactant in the fetal lungs are the Type II pneumocytes. These cells are interspersed among the Type I pneumocytes and are specifically tasked with the synthesis, storage, and secretion of surfactant.

Goblet cells are found in the respiratory and intestinal tracts and are responsible for mucus production, not surfactant production. Bronchial epithelial cells line the airways and are involved in the mucociliary clearance mechanism. Vascular smooth muscle cells are found in the walls of blood vessels and are responsible for regulating vascular tone and blood pressure, not lung maturity.

So, the answer is [C]. Type II pneumocytes.<|end|>

2025-12-10 18:17:05,998 - INFO - question 790/1273 answer:C correct_answer:C True
2025-12-10 18:17:12,116 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 56-year-old patient is being treated with oral amoxicillin for community-acquired pneumonia. The plasma clearance of the drug is calculated as 15.0 L/h. Oral bioavailability of the drug is 75%. Sensitivity analysis of a sputum culture shows a minimal inhibitory concentration of 1 μg/mL for the causative pathogen. The target plasma concentration is 2 mg/L. If the drug is administered twice per day, which of the following dosages should be administered at each dosing interval to maintain a steady state?

[A] : 270 mg
[B] : 480 mg
[C] : 240 mg
[D] : 540 mg
"
<|end|><|assistant|> To calculate the dosage required to maintain a steady state, we can use the following formula:

Dosage = (Clearance × Target plasma concentration) / Bioavailability

Given:
- Clearance (Cl) = 15.0 L/h
- Target plasma concentration (Cp) = 2 mg/L
- Bioavailability (F) = 75% or 0.75

First, we need to calculate the dose required to achieve the target plasma concentration, taking into account the bioavailability:

Dose = (Cl × Cp) / F
Dose = (15.0 L/h × 2 mg/L) / 0.75
Dose = (30 mg/h) / 0.75
Dose = 40 mg/h

Since the drug is administered twice per day, we need to divide the total daily dose by 2 to find the dose per dosing interval:

Dose per interval = Total daily dose / 2
Dose per interval = 40 mg/h × 24 h / 2
Dose per interval = 960 mg / 2
Dose per interval = 480 mg

So, the answer is [B].<|end|>

[D] : Aortic valve stenosis

This can cause symptoms like shortness of breath, fatigue, and dizziness, especially with exertion, as the heart has to work harder to pump blood through the narrowed valve.

Given the patient's age, risk factors, and the likely findings on cardiac examination, aortic valve stenosis is the most likely diagnosis.

So, the answer is [D]. Aortic valve stenosis.<|end|>

Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this finding?

[A] : Increased binding of calcium to calmodulin
[B] : Increased phosphorylation of myosin
[C] : Increased production of nitric oxide
[D] : Decreased concentration of bradykinin
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient's symptoms of headache and blurry vision, along with a history of hypertension, suggest a possible diagnosis of giant cell arteritis (GCA), which is also known as temporal arteritis. GCA is an inflammatory disease of blood vessels (vasculitis) that often affects the temporal arteries and can lead to complications such as blindness. A temporal artery biopsy is a diagnostic procedure for GCA, and one of the histopathological findings in GCA is a decrease in the concentration of arginine in vascular endothelial cells.

Arginine is a substrate for the production of nitric oxide (NO) through the action of nitric oxide synthase (NOS). Nitric oxide is a potent vasodilator and plays a crucial role in maintaining vascular tone and blood pressure. In the context of GCA, the inflammation of the vessel wall can lead to a decrease in the availability of arginine for NO production. This is because the inflammatory process can consume arginine or because the endothelial dysfunction associated with GCA impairs the production of NO.

The other options provided do not directly relate to the decreased concentration of arginine in vascular endothelial cells:

[A]. Increased binding of calcium to calmodulin is a process that can affect various cellular functions, but it is not directly related to the decreased concentration of arginine.
[B]. Increased phosphorylation of myosin is related to muscle contraction and would not be directly related to arginine levels in endothelial cells.
[D]. Decreased concentration of bradykinin is a peptide that causes vasodilation, but it is not directly related to the availability of arginine for NO production.

Given this information, the most likely explanation for the decreased concentration of arginine in vascular endothelial cells is related to the inflammatory process in GCA, which can lead to decreased production of nitric oxide.

So, the answer is [C]. Increased production of nitric oxide.<|end|>

[A] : “I can not help you due to the ethical principle of autonomy.”
[B] : “I can not help you due to the ethical principle of justice.”
[C] : “I can not help you due to the ethical principle of nonmaleficence.”
[D] : “I can not help you due to the ethical principle of beneficence.”

[B]. Justice in healthcare refers to the fair distribution of resources and treatments. While this could be a concern, it is not the primary ethical issue in this scenario.

[A] : IL-28
[B] : TGF-β
[C] : IFN-α
[D] : IL-4
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient's history of asthma, frequent exacerbations, and the presence of eosinophilia (13% eosinophils) and elevated serum immunoglobulin E (IgE) suggest that she is experiencing an allergic or atopic response. The sputum culture showing septate hyphae that branch at 45 degrees is indicative of a fungal infection, likely Aspergillus, which is known to cause allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) in patients with asthma.

ABPA is a hypersensitivity reaction to Aspergillus species that colonize the airways. It is characterized by an exaggerated immune response involving Th2 cells and the production of cytokines such as IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13. These cytokines promote eosinophilic inflammation and IgE production, which are hallmarks of the disease.

IL-28 (also known as IFN-λ) is a type III interferon that has antiviral activity and is not typically associated with allergic responses or asthma.

TGF-β (Transforming Growth Factor Beta) is involved in tissue repair and fibrosis and can be associated with chronic inflammatory diseases, but it is not the primary cytokine involved in the allergic response seen in ABP[A].

IFN-α (Interferon Alpha) is a type I interferon with antiviral properties and is not typically associated with the allergic response seen in ABP[A].

IL-4 (Interleukin 4) is a key cytokine in the Th2 immune response, which is involved in the pathogenesis of ABP[A]. IL-4 promotes the differentiation of naive helper T cells to Th2 cells, the production of IgE by B cells, and the activation of eosinophils.

Given the clinical picture and the typical immune response in ABPA, IL-4 is the cytokine most likely to be increased in this patient.

So, the answer is [D].<|end|>

2025-12-10 18:18:16,466 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 29-year-old G1P0 female presents at 22 weeks gestation for her first prenatal care appointment. Physical exam demonstrates a uterine size greater than expected for her gestational age and taut, shiny skin with scattered striae on her abdomen. Ultrasound examination of the fetus reveals 2.5 L of amniotic fluid (normal 1.5-2.0 L) with an amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 34 (normal AFI 20-25). Which of the following fetal abnormalities or dysfunctions could have contributed to these abnormal ultrasound findings?

[A] : Renal agenesis
[B] : Pulmonary hypoplasia
[C] : Duodenal atresia
[D] : Posterior urethral valve
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient presents with a uterine size greater than expected for her gestational age and excessive amniotic fluid, as indicated by the amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 34, which is above the normal range of 20-25. This condition is known as polyhydramnios.

Polyhydramnios can be associated with several fetal conditions that affect the production or regulation of amniotic fluid. These conditions include gastrointestinal obstructions, such as duodenal atresia, which can prevent the fetus from swallowing and absorbing amniotic fluid properly, leading to an excess.

Renal agenesis (A) would lead to oligohydramnios (too little amniotic fluid) rather than polyhydramnios because the kidneys are responsible for producing urine, which contributes to the amniotic fluid volume.

Pulmonary hypoplasia (B) is a condition where the lungs are underdeveloped, and it is not directly associated with the amount of amniotic fluid.

Posterior urethral valve (D) is a condition that can lead to oligohydramnios due to obstruction of urine flow from the bladder to the urethra, which would decrease the amount of amniotic fluid.

Given these considerations, the fetal abnormality that could have contributed to the abnormal ultrasound findings of polyhydramnios in this case is duodenal atresia (C), which can cause an accumulation of amniotic fluid due to the inability of the fetus to properly swallow and absorb it.

So, the answer is [C]. Duodenal atresia.<|end|>

In the setting of an AMI, the goal is to improve cardiac output and blood pressure to ensure adequate perfusion of vital organs. The medication that would be most appropriate to achieve this is one that stimulates the beta-1 adrenergic receptors.
